School of Energy and Power Engineering University of Shanghai for Science & Technology Shanghai 200093 China Herein, nickel species have been used to optimize the NH3-SCR activity of the tungsten-impregnated 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalyst. The doping of nickel species helps to the formation of spinel NiFe2O4 and also promotes the growth of γ-Fe2O3 and α-Fe2O3 crystals in Fe2O3 supports fabricated via the anaerobic solution followed by the chemical oxidization of hydrogen peroxide, although it decreases the BET surface areas and pore volumes of supports sharply. However, the induced interaction between the formed spinel NiFe2O4 and the impregnated tungsten species depresses the disadvantageous effect of the high-temperature calcination on the formation/growth of γ-Fe2O3/α-Fe2O3 crystals in 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalysts and the collapse of the pore structure of catalyst effectively. Furthermore, the formation of spinel NiFe2O4 after nickel doping contributes to promoting the redox equilibrium of Fe3++Ni2+ ↔ Fe2++Ni3+ via the electronic inductive effect between Fe and Ni ions, thereby improves the surface molar ratio of Oα/(Oα+Oβ), the redox properties as well as the higher molar ratio of Brønsted/Lewis acid sites formed on the surface of 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalyst, but nickel doping is not conducive to the bulk oxygen vacancies of catalyst. Interestingly, the decrease of glucose/urea molar ratio from 10:20 to 7.5:20 strengthens the optimized role of nickel doping on the physical-chemical properties of 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalyst, and there exists a synergetic promotional effect of nickel doping and glucose dosage on its NH3-SCR activity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords NH3-SCR W/Fe2O3 catalysts Nickel doping Glucose dosage Promotional effect Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction As a kind of major pollutants from the combustion of fossil fuels, the emission of nitrogen oxides (NO x ) could bring a series of environmental problems, for instance, acid rain, ozone depletion and photochemical smog [1–3]. Owing to the high de-nitration efficiency, selective catalytic reduction with NH3 (NH3-SCR) has been usually to control the emission of NO x effectively [4]. Certainly, the traditional commercial V-W-Ti catalyst exhibits excellent NH3-SCR activity, but there still exists several inevitable disadvantages such as the toxicity of vanadium species, the formation of N2O at high temperature, and a narrow operating temperature window, limiting its industrial applications [5–7]. Hopefully, in order to overcome the drawbacks of the commercial catalyst, numbers of catalysts with the transition metal oxides as the main components have been studied and developed [8–12]. Among the catalysts investigated, α-Fe2O3-based catalyst exhibits decent de-NO x performance and has been widely applied for the NH3-SCR reaction owing to its high abundance, non-toxicity and noticeable thermal stability [13]. Shao et al. [14] had found that the doping of Co significantly improved the NH3-SCR activity of α-Fe2O3, and the as-prepared Co-Fe catalyst presented the smallest particle size and the largest surface area with higher reducibility and better catalytic oxidization of NO to NO2. In addition, the Fe-Mn catalyst, consisted of nano-porous α-Fe2O3 and amorphous Mn oxides, exhibited an excellent catalytic performance with higher than 90% NO conversion achieved at a temperature range from 130 to 300 °C due to the high surface area, the superior oxidation ability and the abundant amount of Brønsted/Lewis acid sites [15]. Compared with α-Fe2O3, γ-Fe2O3 shows better catalytic performance of NO x reduction on account of its stronger absorption of ammonia species [16,17], thus attracts a lot of attention. Husnain et al. [18] had pointed out that compared to the conventional coprecipitation, the γ-Fe2O3 synthesized via the facile method exhibited regular spherical particles, better reducibility properties and stronger adsorption of reactants by inhibiting the formation of α-Fe2O3 crystal, thus presented better low-temperature NH3-SCR activity. In addition, γ-Fe2O3 has a certain resistance to sulfur poisoning in the middle/high-temperature range. Yu et al. [19] had found that the ferric ions on the surface of γ-Fe2O3 could react with SO4 2− of ammonium sulfates to generate ferric sulfates, resulting in the enhancement of the surface acid sites and adsorbed oxygen, thereby promoted the Eley-Rideal (E-R) reaction pathway of NO x reduction with NH3 on the surface of γ-Fe2O3. Meanwhile, there still exists some problems needing to be addressed like the thermal instability of γ-Fe2O3 to α-Fe2O3 at high temperatures and the negative reaction of ammonia oxidation above 300 °C for γ-Fe2O3 catalyst [1,20]. As a result, some additives recognized as the excellent “structure” and “chemical” promoters have been used to promote the NH3-SCR activity of iron-based catalyst, such as W [21], Mo [22], Mg [23] and Ti [24], etc. Among the additives investigated, tungsten species have been widely adopted as the main component to optimize the NH3-SCR activity of γ-Fe2O3 based catalyst due to the unique electronic properties and strong surface acidity. For example, Yu et al. [25] pointed out that the doped WO3 species contributed to bringing about the strong electronic inductive effects with Fe and Ti ions, stimulating the formation of Fe(3 + n )+-O-W(6 − n )+ and Ti(4 + n )+-O-W(6 − n )+ structures along with the enhancement of chemical adsorbed oxygen and surface hydroxyl species, thus obviously promoted the catalytic performance of NO x reduction over the FeTiO x catalyst. Furthermore, as a good promotional additive of surface acid sites, the doping of tungsten species effectively promotes the NH3-SCR activity of γ-Fe2O3 catalyst and broadens its low-medium temperature reaction activity temperature window by improving the surface acid sites of catalyst and preventing the irreversible transformation of the γ-Fe2O3 active components into α-Fe2O3 [17,26]. Owing to the good stability, large surface area, small volume density and high porosity, nickel species have also been used to improve the catalytic performance of NO x conversion with NH3 [27]. Liu et al. [28] had found that the doping of Ni brought about more Ni2+ formed on the surface of Ce-Ti oxide catalyst, resulting in the formation of more oxygen vacancies. They reported that the introduction of nickel species induced the interaction between cerium and nickel species, leading to the stronger redox ability and the formation of amorphous structure, which contributed to the highly remarkable catalytic activity of NO x reduction over the as-prepared Ni-Ce-Ti oxide catalyst at a wide operation temperature range. In addition, Ni doping also plays an important role on hindering the over-oxidation of NH3 at high temperature, contributing to the broad activity temperature window and superior N2 selectivity of catalyst, which was proved by the NimCo0.3-mTi0.7O x catalyst [29]. Furthermore, Gao et al. [30] found that the doping of Ni not only helped to enrich the active sites and the chemisorbed oxygen on the surface of MnO x -CeO2 catalyst, but also effectively inhibited the formation of ammonium sulfate and metal sulfate species, and the bidentate nitrate of NO x adsorbed species was promoted by doping Ni, which was then weakly influenced by SO2. However, there are few researches about the NH3-SCR activity of nickel-doped γ-Fe2O3-based catalyst. One possible reason is that the unstable thermal γ-Fe2O3 easily irreversibly converts into α-Fe2O3 at relatively high temperatures [20,31]. Nevertheless, similar to the effect of tungsten doping, the stability of the γ-Fe2O3-based materials could also be remarkably enhanced by nickel doping due to the formation of spinel structure NiFe2O4 crystal. This spinel structure is usually defined as the closely packed cubic structures with Fe3+ as the trivalent cation while Ni2+ occupies the divalent cation, contributing to ensuring the thermal stability and the oxygen storage capacity of Fe-Ni spinel structure materials [32]. For instance, the coexistence and cooperation of NiFe2O4 and Ni6MnO8 crystals helped to generate more surface acid sites of the NiMnFe-mixed oxide catalyst, and the induced electron transfer between Ni and Fe/Mn ions promoted a more rapid redox cycle, which consequently accomplished the superior de-NO x performance of catalyst [33]. In addition, Wang et al. [34] had pointed out that the emerged NiFe2O4 at a higher calcination temperature was indeed conducive to the generation of more Fe species on the surface of Fe-Ni mixed oxide catalyst and contributed to its stable structure, better high-temperature activity and preferable SO2 resistance. Furthermore, nickel species also had been used to regulate the crystal structure and the surface morphology of γ-Fe2O3-based catalyst with the internal chemical bond of Fe-O-Ni structure formed and evidently improved the chemical stability and BET surface area of γ-Fe2O3 [35,36]. Regarding the influence of nickel doping on the physical and chemical properties of iron-based materials, it is optimistic to obtain novel Ni-doped W/Fe2O3 with enhanced catalytic performance of NO x reduction. In the present work, nickel species were doped into the γ-Fe2O3 support synthesized via a saved energy and time method that combines the anaerobic solution combustion with the hydrothermal oxidation of hydrogen peroxide, and four kinds of γ-Fe2O3 and Fe2NiO z supports were fabricated by controlling the molar ratio of glucose/urea being 10:20 and 7.5:20, respectively. On this basis, the influence of nickel doping or/and glucose dosage on the NH3-SCR activity of 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalyst prepared via the impregnation method were studied. Subsequently, the synergetic effect of nickel doping and glucose dosage on the crystal structure, pore structure, redox properties and surface acidity of 7.5 W/Fe2O3 catalyst were investigated by applying various experimental techniques, including the X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 adsorption-desorption, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) and pyridine adsorption infrared spectroscopy (Py-IR). 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation By keeping the molar ratio of Ni/Fe and the mass ratio of glucose/urea being 0:1/1:2 and 7.5:20/10:20, four kinds of γ-Fe2O3 and Fe2NiO z supports were synthesized via the anaerobic solution combustion coupled with the hydrothermal oxidation of hydrogen peroxide, which had been reported in our previous research [26], Firstly, a certain amount of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O/Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, glucose and urea were dissolved in the 10 ml deionized water. And a uniformly light green mixture was obtained after being stirred for an hour in room temperature. Then, the solution was ignited at 400 °C in a muffle furnace at the absence of air. After a large of gases escaped, a dark black powder composed of the iron-nickel oxide and the residual carbon were obtained, which was then oxidized using 30 wt.% hydrogen peroxide by keeping the solid-liquid ratio being 1:20. Subsequently, the mixture was stirred in a water bath at 65 °C and 95 °C for 1 h, respectively. Finally, after being filtered and washed with deionized water and absolute ethanol for several times, the resulted supports were dried at 105 °C for 2 h and named as Fe2O3-GC:UA=10:20-P, Fe2O3-GC:UA=7.5:20-P, Fe2NiO z -GC:UA=10:20-P and Fe2NiO z -GC:UA=7.5:20-P, respectively. Tungsten species were impregnated on the above γ-Fe2O3 or Fe2NiO z supports. Herein, a certain amount of ammonium tungstate and oxalic acid were fully dissolved in 10 ml deionized water with the mass ratio of WO3 and the above supports being 7.5wt.%. After being stirred for 2 h, the mixture solution was dried at 105 °C for 8 h and then calcined at 400 °C for 5 h at the heating rate of 1.5 °C/min. Hereinafter, the obtained samples, correspondingly designated as 7.5W/Fe2O3-GC:UA=10:20, 7.5W/Fe2O3-GC:UA=7.5:20, 7.5W/Fe2NiO z -GC:UA=10:20 and 7.5W/Fe2NiO z -GC:UA=7.5:20, were pressed, crushed and sieved to 40–60 meshes before the NH3-SCR experiments. 2.2 Catalysts characterization The XRD pattern was recorded through an X-ray diffraction meter (Japan, Shimadzu, Cu Kα radiation and λ = 0.15406 nm) between 20° and 80° at a step rate of 2°/min operated at 40 kV and 30 mA. Micromeritics ASAP 2460 system apparatus was applied to obtain the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm at 77 K. The BET surface areas and the pore size distributions of the samples were determined via the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method, respectively. The X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were carried out on the ESCALAB250 Scanning X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (USA, Thermo-Fisher Scientific) with Al Ka radiation, using C 1 s peak (BE = 284.86 eV) to calibrate the binding energy of Fe 2p,Ni 2p,W 4f and O 1 s. The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were carried out on a Bruker A300 (9.853 GHz) spectrometer at normal atmospheric temperature. The temperature-programmed reduction of H2 (H2-TPR) was performed on AutoChem II with TCD detection (Micromeritics, USA). Firstly, the sample (50 mg) was preheated under high purified Ar atmosphere (30 mL/min) at 300 °C for 30 min, and then cooled down to 50 °C. Subsequently, the procedure of TPR started from 50 °C to 900 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min in H2(10 vol.%)/Ar(40 mL/min). The temperature-programmed desorption of NH3 (NH3-TPD) was also measured on AutoChem II with TCD detection (Micromeritics, USA), 100 mg sample was pretreated under the He atmosphere at 500 °C for 1 h, and then cooled to 100 °C. Subsequently, the sample was saturated with 20 vol.% NH3/He mixed gases at 100 °C and purged again in high-purity He atmosphere for 1 h to remove gaseous and weakly physically adsorbed NH3. Finally, desorption was performed by heating the sample in pure He atmosphere from 100 to 500 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. The pyridine adsorption infrared spectroscopy (Py-IR) was acquired by using Thermo Nicolet 380 spectrometer to investigate the acidity of the catalysts. Prior to pyridine adsorption, the samples were pretreated at 200 °C under vacuum condition and then cooled down to room temperature. Subsequently, 20 mL/min He flow saturated with pyridine was introduced into the IR cell at room temperature for 2 h to ensure that all acid sites were covered. After that, the desorption of pyridine was carried out by evacuation for 30 min under vacuum at 150 °C and 300 °C, respectively. And IR spectra were collected at specific temperature. 2.3 Catalytic performance measurement The NH3-SCR performance of the as-prepared catalysts was evaluated in a fixed-bed quartz reactor by using 1.8 g sample with the sieve fraction of 40–60 mesh. The simulated gas mixture contained 600 ppm NH3, 600 ppm NO, 5 vol.% O2, and 99.999% N2 as balance with the total rate of reaction gas being 1500 mL/min, corresponding to the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 50,000 mL/(g·h). The NO x conversion for the NH3-SCR reaction was calculated using the following equations: N O x conversion ( % ) = [ N O x ] in − [ N O x ] out [ N O x ] in × 100 % Where [NO x ]in and [NO x ]out represent the inlet and outlet concentrations of NO x , respectively, and NO x = NO + NO2. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 NH3-SCR activity According to our previous research, a two-step method that combines the anaerobic solution combustion with the hydrothermal oxidation of hydrogen peroxide was applied to synthesize the large BET surface area Fe2O3 supports by using the analytical magnitude Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, urea and glucose. Different from urea, glucose is not only used as the fuel, but also as the carbon-template to increase the dispersion of iron oxide crystal and inhibit its growth and agglomeration at high temperature owing to the carbonization of partial glucose during the anaerobic solution combustion. Consequently, two kinds of glucose/urea molar ratios, 10:20 and 7.5:20, were chosen to investigate the synergetic promotional effect of glucose dosage and nickel doping on the NH3-SCR activity of 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalyst by substituting one third molar ratio of Fe(NO3)3·9H2O with Ni(NO3)2·6H2O before the anaerobic solution combustion. As shown in Fig. 1 , it can be seen that 7.5W/Fe2O3-GC:UA=10:20 and 7.5W/Fe2O3-GC:UA=7.5:20 catalysts present similar NH3-SCR activity with above 90% NO x conversion obtained at 275–350 °C, although the latter shows a little better low/medium-temperature catalytic performance. However, the doping of nickel species evidently increases the NH3-SCR activity of 7.5W/Fe2O3-GC:UA=10:20 and 7.5W/Fe2O3-GC:UA=7.5:20 accordingly, and 7.5W/Fe2NiO z -GC:UA=7.5:20 exhibits the best catalytic performance of NO x reduction with NH3. Therefore, the dosage of glucose indeed influences the promotional effect of nickel doping on the NH3-SCR activity of 7.5 W/Fe2O3, and there exists a synergetic promotional effect of glucose dosage and nickel doping on the performance of the NH3-SCR reaction. 3.2 The properties of crystallite (XRD) Due to the partial carbonization of glucose during the anaerobic solution combustion, the decrease of glucose/urea molar ratio from 10:20 to 7.5:20 might reduce the formation of residual carbon particles, thus influence the crystalline of Fe2O3 supports and the interaction between iron and nickel species in Fe2NiO z supports, eventually leading to the alteration of the physical properties and de-nitration performance of 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalyst. Therefore, we firstly investigated the influence of nickel doping and glucose dosage on the XRD patterns of Fe2O3 supports and their corresponding catalysts, and the results are shown in Fig. 2 . As shown in Fig. 2(A), it can be seen clearly that no characteristic peaks assigned to iron oxide crystal were detected for Fe2O3-GC:UA=7.5:20-P or/and Fe2O3-GC:UA=10:20-P supports, and the latter presents two wide peaks at 20⁓40° which are attributed to the residual carbon even if it had been oxidized by hydrogen peroxide [37]. However, the doping of nickel species not only helps to the formation of NiFe2O4 crystal, but also promotes the crystallinity and growth of γ-Fe2O3 (PDF#39–1346), α-Fe2O3 (PDF#33–0664) and Carbon (PDF#50–0926), which might be in an amorphous phase or highly dispersed in Fe2O3 supports. Furthermore, Fe2NiO z -GC:UA=10:20-P presents stronger diffraction peak of NiFe2O4 crystal than Fe2NiO z -GC:UA=7.5:20-P. Therefore, the substitution of partial Fe(NO3)3·9H2O with Ni(NO3)2·6H2O promotes the formation or/and growth of iron-based crystals including NiFe2O4, γ-Fe2O3 and α-Fe2O3 in supports, but the enhancement of glucose/urea molar ratio from 7.5:20 to 10:20 increases the amount of the residual carbon in Fe2O3 support and promotes the growth of NiFe2O4 crystal in Fe2NiO z support. Unfortunately, according to the results in Fig. 2(B), both 7.5W/Fe2O3-GC:UA=10:20 and 7.5W/Fe2O3-GC:UA=7.5:20 exhibit the sharp diffraction peaks attributed to α-Fe2O3 (2θ=24.1°, 33.2°, 40.8°, 49.5°, 54.1°, 62.4°, 64.0°, PDF#33–0664) and γ-Fe2O3 (2θ=35.6°,57.3°, PDF#39–1346) because of the calcination at 400 °C for 5 h even if tungsten species were impregnated on the surface of supports [38]. Interestingly, the doping of nickel species effectively depresses the growth of α-Fe2O3 and γ-Fe2O3 crystals in 7.5W/Fe2O3, especially α-Fe2O3. Furthermore, both 7.5W/Fe2NiO z -GC:UA=7.5:20 and 7.5W/Fe2NiO z -GC:UA=10:20 exhibit much weaker diffraction peaks assigned to spinel NiFe2O4 than their corresponding supports. This demonstrates that there exists a good interaction between the impregnated tungsten species and the formed spinel NiFe2O4 in 7.5W/Fe2NiO z catalysts, which makes the diffraction peaks of spinel NiFe2O4 almost disappear even if the catalysts had been calcined at 400 °C for 5 h. Meanwhile, the enhancement of glucose/urea molar ratio from 7.5:20 to10:20 promotes the growth of α-Fe2O3 and γ-Fe2O3 crystal in 7.5W/Fe2O3 and 7.5W/Fe2NiO z catalysts, respectively. This might decrease their low/medium-temperature NH3-SCR activity (Fig. 1). It should be mentioned that no diffraction peaks attributed to tungsten species had been detected for all four catalysts, demonstrating that the impregnated tungsten species might be an amorphous phase or highly dispersed in them [39]. According to the results of our previous researches [17,26,40], the impregnation of tungsten species contributed to hindering the irreversible transformation of γ-Fe2O3 into α-Fe2O3 during the calcined process at 400 °C for 5 h, thereby increased the NH3-SCR activity of Fe2O3 catalyst. Therefore, it can be deduced that the above influence of tungsten oxides on hindering the irreversible transformation of γ-Fe2O3 is enhanced by doping nickel species via the interaction between the spinel NiFe2O4 and impregnated tungsten species, but the increase of glucose/urea more ratio from 7.5:20 to10:20 slightly suppresses this interaction, which is unhelpful to the catalytic performance of 7.5W/Fe2O3 and 7.5W/Fe2NiO z catalysts. 3.3 N2 adsorption-desorption Herein, the 7.5W/Fe2O3 and 7.5W/Fe2NiO z catalysts were synthesized via the impregnation method by dipping tungsten species on the surface of Fe2O3 and Fe2NiO z supports, thus the pore structure and BET surface area of supports are crucial to the NH3-SCR activity of the as-prepared catalysts. Fig. 3 (A) and (B) give the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of Fe2O3/Fe2NiO z supports and their corresponding pore size distributions, respectively. It can be found that Fe2O3-GC:UA=10:20-P presents the typical Ⅰ N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm with large micro-porous formed. Meanwhile, the decrease of glucose/urea molar ratio from 10:20 to 7.5 helps to the formation of partial meso‑porous in Fe2O3 support simultaneously. And there exists an IV-type hysteresis for the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm of Fe2O3-GC:UA=7.5:20-P according to the IUPAC classification, demonstrating the presence of both micro- and meso‑porous in it [41,42]. However, the doping of nickel species greatly reduces the interaction between nitrogen and Fe2O3-GC:UA=10:20-P, and Fe2NiO z -GC:UA=10:20-P exhibits a typical V N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm with a certain amount of macro-porous formed in it due to the rising gas adsorption capacity at higher relative pressure. Different from the former, Fe2NiO z -GC:UA=7.5:20-P has larger micro- and macro-porous according to its typical IV N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm [43,44]. Therefore, the doping of nickel species is unhelpful to the formation of micro/meso‑porous for Fe2O3 support, but the decrease of glucose/urea molar ratio from 10:20 to 7.5:20 definitely promotes the formation of meso‑porous of supports, which has been confirmed by the pore size distributions in Fig. 3(B). Fe2O3 supports have large micro/meso‑porous less than 6 nm, while Fe2NiO z supports exhibit more meso‑ and macro-porous at 6–100 nm, especially Fe2NiO z -GC:UA=7.5:20-P. By comparing the results in Fig. 3(A) and (C), it can be found that the impregnation of tungsten species coupled the activation calcination at 400 °C for 5 h leads to the collapse of micro-porous of Fe2O3 supports, and 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalysts present the typical IV N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms with H2 Hysteresis loop, indicating abundant homogeneous meso‑porous are formed in them. However, 7.5W/Fe2NiO z catalysts exhibit the typical IV N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms with H3 Hysteresis loop, demonstrating large slit pore are formed in them due to the accumulation of flake particles [45,46]. The results in Fig. 3(D) indicate that there exist two peaks ranging from 3–5 nm and 6–10 nm for the pore size distributions of 7.5W/Fe2O3-GC:UA=10:20 and 7.5W/Fe2O3-GC:UA=7.5:20. Meanwhile, the 7.5W/Fe2NiO z catalysts present the wider pore size distribution with a narrow and sharp peak located at about 5 nm. Furthermore, the differential pore volumes of 7.5W/Fe2NiO z catalysts are also stronger than their corresponding supports. This demonstrates that the impregnated tungsten species authentically contributes to enriching the pore structure of supports via their good interaction with spinel NiFe2O4 crystal even if the catalysts had been calcined at 400 °C for 5 h. Therefore, the doping of nickel species promotes the formation of pore structure of 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalyst via the good interaction between the impregnated tungsten species and the formed spinel NiFe2O4 crystal, and this promotional effect can be strengthened further by decreasing the molar ratio of glucose/urea from 10:20 to 7.5:20. The BET surface areas, pore volumes and average pore diameters of Fe2O3/Fe2NiO z supports and their corresponding catalysts were calculated and listed in Table 1 and Fig. S1. The results in Table 1 indicate that Fe2O3 supports exhibit larger BET surface area and pore volume than Fe2NiO z supports owing to the existence of a larger number of micro-porous. In addition, the decrease of glucose/urea molar ratio from 10:20 to 7.5:20 increases the BET surface areas and pore volumes of Fe2O3 or/and Fe2NiO z supports, although this treatment can bring more residual carbon template formed in the carbon-based particles after the anaerobic solution combustion, which contributes to preventing the agglomeration of Fe2O3/Fe2NiO z crystal and hindering the growth of their particle sizes [47]. This demonstrates that the formation of more residual carbon template is unhelpful to the pore structure of the above supports. This might be because of the stronger pore structure collapse during the hydrothermal oxidation of hydrogen peroxide. It should be mentioned that 7.5W/Fe2O3-GC:UA=10:20 and 7.5W/Fe2O3-GC:UA=7.5:20 present much smaller BET surface area and pore volume than their corresponding supports, although the impregnated tungsten species had been confirmed to maintain well pore structure by preventing the collapse of pore structure, the irreversible transformation of γ-Fe2O3 into α-Fe2O3 and the growth of iron-based crystals during the calcined process at 400 °C for 5 h [17,26]. Interestingly, the impregnation of tungsten species optimizes the pore structure of Fe2NiO z supports well, and improves their BET surface areas and pore volumes greatly due to the good interaction between the impregnated tungsten species and the formed NiFe2O4 crystal, which has been confirmed by the XRD results in Fig. 2. Simultaneously, large BET surface area indeed helps to improve the dispersion of the impregnated tungsten species on the surface of Fe2O3 supports, but this might inhibit the effect of tungsten species on preventing the irreversible transformation of γ-Fe2O3 into α-Fe2O3 and the growth of iron-based crystals when the impregnated amount of tungsten species remains unchanged. It is known that larger surface area and pore volume can provide more active sites for gaseous reactants to be adsorbed and activated, thus improve the mass transfer rates between active sites and reactants or intermediate, which are closely related to the performance of NH3-SCR activity [48]. In general, the doping of nickel species is unhelpful to the pore structure of Fe2O3 supports, but the formed NiFe2O4 crystal promotes the interaction between the impregnated tungsten and the supports, which makes 7.5W/Fe2NiO z exhibit larger BET surface area and pore volume than 7.5W/Fe2O3. Furthermore, the decrease of glucose/urea molar ratio from 10:20 to 7.5:20 contributes to increasing the BET surface areas and pore volumes of Fe2O3/Fe2NiO z supports and their corresponding tungsten impregnated catalysts, thus enhances the NH3-SCR activity of 7.5W/Fe2O3 and 7.5W/Fe2NiO z catalysts. 3.4 Chemical state of surface composition (XPS and EPR) The XPS measurement was carried out to investigate the influence of nickel doping and glucose dosage on the surface chemical composition of 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalyst and the interaction of its components, and the corresponding XPS spectra of Ni 2p, Fe 2p, W 4f and O 1 s are presented in Fig. 4 . In previous researches, we had found that the impregnation of tungsten species could make the binding energy of Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 for Fe2O3 shift to a higher position by decreasing the electron density of iron species on the surface of 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalyst via the interaction of tungsten and iron species [26]. From Fig. 4(A), it can be found that the decrease of glucose/urea molar ratio from 10:20 to 7.5:20 almost exhibits no effect of the binding energy assigned to Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2, and only lowers the molar ratio of Fe2+/(Fe2++Fe3+) from 30.3% to 29.4% on the surface of 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalyst. However, the doping of nickel species makes the binding energy of Fe 2p spectra shift to a higher position, indicating the further decrease of electron density assigned to iron species on the surface of 7.5 W/Fe2O3 catalyst because of the interaction between the doped nickel species and iron/tungsten species. Thus, the doped nickel species lead to a deviation driven of the electron cloud of Fe ions and change their 3d orbital electron density and eg-orbital filling, which accelerates the electron transfer between Ni and Fe ions in catalyst [49]. In addition, the decrease of glucose/urea molar ratio from 10:20 to 7.5:20 further increases the molar ratio of Fe2+/(Fe2++Fe3+) on the surface of 7.5W/Fe2NiO z catalyst, and 7.5W/Fe2NiO z -GC:UA=7.5:20 presents the largest surface Fe2+/(Fe2++Fe3+) molar ratio. Actually, the intermediate valence of Fe2+ species had usually been thought to promote the formation of unsaturated bond and enhance the mobility of electron, leading to higher NH3-SCR activity of iron-based catalyst [50,51]. As shown in Fig. 4(B), the spectra of Ni 2p3/2 can be deconvoluted into three peaks located at 854.1–854.4 eV, 855.7–856.1 eV and 861.2–861.5 eV, which are assigned to Ni2+, Ni3+ and satellite peaks, respectively [52]. Meanwhile, 7.5W/Fe2NiO z -GC:UA=10:20 exhibits larger surface molar ratio of Ni2+/(Ni2++Ni3+) than 7.5W/Fe2NiO z -GC:UA=7.5:20. Therefore, owing to the doping of nickel species, the formation of spinel NiFe2O4 contributes to promoting the redox equilibrium of Fe3++Ni2+ ↔ Fe2++Ni3+ via the electronic inductive effect of Fe and Ni ions. Furthermore, as depicted in Figs. 4(C) and 2, the good interaction between spinel NiFe2O4 and the impregnated tungsten species also makes the binding energy of W4f spectra shift to a higher position, and the doping of nickel specie strengthens the partial substitution of Fe3+ions by W6+, which contributes to enhancing the molar ratio of Fe2+/(Fe2++Fe3+) and W dispersion on the surface of catalyst. The results in Fig. 4(D) indicate that there exists both the lattice oxygen (529.9–530.2 eV, Oβ) derived from metal oxides and the chemisorbed oxygen from oxide defects or hydroxyl groups (530.8–531.2 eV, Oα) [53–55]. Both the doping of nickel species and the decrease of glucose/urea molar ratio from 10:20 to 7.5:20 improve the molar ratio of Oα/(Oα + Oβ) on the surface of 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalyst, and there exists a synergistic promotional effect of nickel species doping and glucose dosage on the migration ability of oxygen. It is acknowledged that the chemisorbed oxygen Oα is conducive to the oxidization of NO to NO2 due to its higher mobility, facilitating the “fast SCR” reaction (4NH3+2NO+2NO2→4N2+6H2O) and increasing the NH3-SCR catalytic performance [56,57]. Therefore, according to the XPS results in Fig. 4 and Table 2 , the doping of nickel species contributes to promoting the redox equilibrium of Fe3++Ni2+ ↔ Fe2++Ni3+ due to the formation of spinel NiFe2O4 and also strengthens the partial substitution of Fe3+ions by W6+ via the good interaction of spinel NiFe2O4 and the impregnated tungsten species, thus increases the surface molar ratios of Fe2+/(Fe2++Fe3+) and Oα/(Oα + Oβ), which can be further promoted by decreasing the glucose/urea molar ratio from 10:20 to 7.5:20, thereby facilitates the NH3-SCR activity of catalyst. Meanwhile, the existence of oxygen vacancy has also usually been thought to help to consume NO and NH3 continually, which can inspire a favorable dynamic balance in NH3-SCR process [58]. Thus, the EPR testing had been measured to investigate the influence of nickel doping and glucose dosage on the oxygen vacancy on the surface of 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalysts. According to the EPR results in Fig. 5 , it can be found that there exists a remarkable signal at g = 2.002 for all catalysts, attributed to the typical character of unpaired electrons at the oxygen vacancy [59]. However, the decrease of glucose/urea molar ratio or/and nickel doping reduce the signal intensity of the oxygen vacancy significantly. Particularly, 7.5W/Fe2NiO z -GC:UA=7.5:20 presents the lowest oxygen vacancy compared to the other investigated catalysts, which is different from the influence of nickel doping and glucose dosage on the results of the chemisorbed oxygen obtained by XPS analysis to some extent. It should be mentioned that XPS only gives the information of oxygen on the surface layers of metal oxides, while EPR characterization reflects the average structures of the inner lattice bulk [60]. Therefore, we can deduce that the chemisorbed oxygen might present a stronger promotional effect on facilitating the NH3-SCR reaction than the bulk oxygen vacancy. Furthermore, Fang et al. [61] had pointed out that the weak EPR signal corresponded to the low number of bulk oxygen vacancy, which might be due to the incorporation of metal ions into the interstitial structure of the lattice, and the weak EPR signal generally indicated the severe lattice distortion and highly unsaturated coordination environment in which the coordinated unsaturated metal ions usually existed as the active centers of the NH3-SCR reaction. Thus, the decrease of glucose/urea molar ratio or/and nickel doping might bring a severe lattice distortion and highly unsaturated coordination environment of 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalyst, thus increase its NH3-SCR activity although this reduces the bulk oxygen vacancy of catalyst. 3.5 Redox property and surface acidity (H2-TPR, NH3-TPD and Py-IR) Owing to the important role of redox properties on the NH3-SCR activity, the H2-TPR technique was employed to investigate the influence of nickel doping and glucose dosage on the redox property of 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalyst in the present work. As depicted in Fig. 6 , 7.5W/Fe2O3-GC:UA=10:20 and 7.5W/Fe2O3-GC:UA=7.5:20 exhibit almost the same H2-TPR reduction pattern, and the decrease of glucose/urea molar ratio from 10:20 to 7.5:20 only leads the H2-TPR pattern of 7.5W/Fe2O3-GC:UA=10:20 shift to low-temperature slightly. Based on the fitting law of Fe2O3 [62–64], the H2-TPR patterns of both 7.5W/Fe2O3-GC:UA=10:20 and 7.5W/Fe2O3-GC:UA=7.5:20 can be divided into six sub-peaks, which are mainly assigned to the stepwise reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4, Fe3O4 to FeO and FeO to Fe0, respectively. However, the doping of nickel specie effectively lowers the reduction temperature of H2 of the above 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalysts, and makes their H2-TPR patterns shift to low-temperature direction. Therefore, the doped nickel species contribute to the reduction of iron oxide via the induced redox equilibrium of Fe3++Ni2+ ↔ Fe2++Ni3+ due to the formation of spinel NiFe2O4, especially the second reduction stage of iron oxide. In previous research, we had found that the impregnated tungsten species decreased the reducibility of iron oxide, which helped to inhibit the non-selective catalytic oxidation of NH3 at high temperatures, thus effectively improved the high-temperature NH3-SCR activity of iron oxide [26]. However, the results in Figs. 1 and 6 demonstrate that the doping of nickel species promote the redox properties of 7.5 W/Fe2O3 catalysts and their catalytic performance of NO x reduction at full tested temperature range. A reasonable and responsible reason for this phenomenon is that the good interaction between the impregnated tungsten species and the formed spinel NiFe2O4 crystal with small BET surface area, proved by the results of XRD and N2 adsorption-desorption, doesn't increase the reduction temperature of Fe2NiO z supports like the inhibitory effect of tungsten impregnation on the redox properties of iron oxide. It should be mentioned that the decrease of glucose/urea molar ratio from 10:20 to 7.5:20 also improves the second reduction stage of 7.5W/Fe2NiO z catalyst, which strengthens the promotional effect of nickel doping on the redox properties of 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalyst. In order to study the effect of nickel doping and glucose dosage on the surface acidity of 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalyst, NH3-TPD was measured and the results are shown in Fig. 7 . It is acknowledged that the desorption peak of NH3 species below 200 °C corresponds to the weak acid sites, while the peaks in the high temperature range (200⁓500 °C) can be ascribed to the desorption of NH3 species from the mid-strong and strong acid sites [65–67], respectively. Therefore, the NH3-TPD patterns of both 7.5W/Fe2O3 and 7.5W/Fe2NiO z catalysts had been divided into seven sub-peaks and the calculated relative proportions of weak, mid-strong and strong acid sites are shown in Table 3 . It is clear that the decrease of glucose/urea molar ratio from 10:20 to 7.5:20 contributes to improving the calculated relative proportions of weak and strong acid sites for both 7.5W/Fe2O3 and 7.5W/Fe2NiO z catalysts, but 7.5W/Fe2O3-GC:UA=7.5:20 catalyst exhibits the worst surface acidity, which is only 0.8 times the NH3 desorption amount of 7.5W/Fe2O3-GC:UA=10:20. However, the doping of nickel species improves the surface acidity of 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalysts, especially the strong acid sites. In addition, the decrease of glucose/urea molar ratio from 10:20 to 7.5:20 strengthens this promotional effect of nickel doping, and 7.5W/Fe2NiO z -GC:UA=7.5:20 presents the strongest surface acidity, which is about 1.5 times the NH3 desorption amount of 7.5W/Fe2O3-GC:UA=10:20. According to the results in Fig. 1, 7.5W/Fe2NiO z -GC:UA=7.5:20 shows the best NH3-SCR activity, but 7.5W/Fe2O3-GC:UA=7.5:20 presents better catalytic performance of NO x reduction than 7.5W/Fe2O3-GC:UA=10:20 although it has the worst surface acidity. Generally, it is acknowledged that only the information of surface acidity is obtained via the NH3-TPD measurement, while the chemisorption of pyridine measured by infrared spectra (Py-IR) has been widely used to discover the nature of the acid site of catalyst. Therefore, the Py-IR of the as-prepared catalysts was tested and the results are given in Fig. 8 . As shown in Fig. 8, the bands of Py-IR obtained at 150 and 300 °C for the as-synthesized catalysts can be assigned to the weak and medium-strong acid sites, respectively. Among them, the band at around 1540 cm−1 is attributed to the CN stretching of pyridine ions adsorbed to the Brønsted acid sites, while the bands at around 1440 and 1580 and 1610 cm−1 are assigned to the vibration of pyridine physically adsorbed to the Lewis acid sites [68–70]. In addition, the band at around 1490 cm−1 corresponds to the interaction of pyridine molecules with both the Brønsted and Lewis acid sites [71]. Obviously, the Lewis acid sites are stronger than the Brønsted acid sites, which are the main acid sites for all the as-prepared catalyst. Meanwhile, both the decrease of glucose/urea molar ratio from 10:20 to 7.5:20 and the doping of nickel reduce the intensity of the weak Lewis acid sites of catalyst, but the latter brings a slight increase of the weak Brønsted acid sites. In order to reveal the influence of glucose dosage and nickel doping on the acid sites of catalyst, the quantitative amounts of Lewis/Brønsted acid sites obtained at 150 and 300 °C via the Py-IR measurement are calculated and given in Table 4 . According to the results in Table 4, it can be found that the decrease of glucose/urea molar ratio from 10:20 to 7.5:20 reduces the weak acid of 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalyst, including the Lewis and Brønsted acid sites, but slightly increases its medium-strong Lewis and Brønsted acid sites. However, the doping of nickel enhances the weak Brønsted acid sites of 7.5W/Fe2O3-GC:UA=10:20 slightly, although it also reduces the Lewis acid sites and the medium-strong Brønsted acid sites of catalyst. Interestingly, the further decrease of the glucose/urea molar ratio from 10:20 to 7.5:20 increases both the Lewis and Brønsted acid sites of 7.5W/Fe2NiO z -GC:UA=10:20, including the weak and medium-strong acid. As a consequence, 7.5W/Fe2NiO z -GC:UA=7.5:20 possesses the maximum Brønsted acid sites and a superior ratio of Brønsted/Lewis acid sites. It had been reported that the Lewis acid sites could effectively adsorb the NH3 species, while the Brønsted acid sites contributed to inhibiting the oxidation of NH3 in the high temperature, which is favorable to the generation of the coordinated ammonia species and NH4+ and the oxidization of NO to NO2 during the NH3-SCR reaction [72,73]. Combined with the NH3-TPD and NH3-SCR results, it can be deduced that the surface acidity might not be the decisive influencing factor on the NH3-SCR activity of the studied catalyst, but higher molar ratio of Brønsted/Lewis acid sites contributes to improving the NH3-SCR activity of 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalyst, which is enhanced by decreasing the glucose/urea molar ratio or/and doping nickel species. 4 Conclusion In this work, novel Fe2NiO z supports were fabricated via the anaerobic solution combustion followed by the hydrothermal oxidation of hydrogen peroxide, and the influence of nickel doping was investigated on the physical-chemical properties and the NH3-SCR activity of 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalyst synthesized by the impregnation method. We found that the doping of nickel species contributes to the formation of spinel NiFe2O4 crystal and also promotes the growth of iron-based crystals in Fe2O3 supports, including γ-Fe2O3 and α-Fe2O3, although it decreases the BET surface areas and pore volumes of Fe2O3-GC:UA=10:20-P and Fe2O3-GC:UA=7.5:20 sharply. However, the good interaction between the formed spinel NiFe2O4 and the impregnated tungsten species depresses the disadvantageous effect of the calcination at 400 °C for 5 h on the formation/growth of γ-Fe2O3/α-Fe2O3 crystals in 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalysts and the collapse of pore structure of catalyst. Furthermore, the decrease of glucose/urea molar ratio from 10:20 to 7.5:20 could strengthen this promotional effect of nickel doping, and there exists a synergetic promotional effect of nickel doping and glucose dosage on the NH3-SCR activity of 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalyst. Among the tested catalysts, 7.5W/Fe2NiO z -GC:UA=7.5:20 presents the best catalytic performance with nearly 100% NO x conversion achieved in a broad temperature window of 250–350 °C. At the same time, the formation of spinel NiFe2O4 after nickel doping contributes to promoting the redox equilibrium of Fe3++Ni2+ ↔ Fe2++Ni3+ via the electronic inductive effect between Fe and Ni ions, thereby improves the molar ratio of Oα/(Oα+Oβ) and the redox properties of 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalyst, which is further strengthened by decreasing the molar ratio of glucose/urea from 10:20 to 7.5:20. Finally, the influence of nickel doping and glucose dosage on the surface acidity of 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalyst was revealed. coredata.dc:description: Herein, nickel species have been used to optimize the NH3-SCR activity of the tungsten-impregnated 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalyst. The doping of nickel species helps to the formation of spinel NiFe2O4 and also promotes the growth of γ-Fe2O3 and α-Fe2O3 crystals in Fe2O3 supports fabricated via the anaerobic solution followed by the chemical oxidization of hydrogen peroxide, although it decreases the BET surface areas and pore volumes of supports sharply. However, the induced interaction between the formed spinel NiFe2O4 and the impregnated tungsten species depresses the disadvantageous effect of the high-temperature calcination on the formation/growth of γ-Fe2O3/α-Fe2O3 crystals in 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalysts and the collapse of the pore structure of catalyst effectively. Furthermore, the formation of spinel NiFe2O4 after nickel doping contributes to promoting the redox equilibrium of Fe3++Ni2+ ↔ Fe2++Ni3+ via the electronic inductive effect between Fe and Ni ions, thereby improves the surface molar ratio of Oα/(Oα+Oβ), the redox properties as well as the higher molar ratio of Brønsted/Lewis acid sites formed on the surface of 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalyst, but nickel doping is not conducive to the bulk oxygen vacancies of catalyst. Interestingly, the decrease of glucose/urea molar ratio from 10:20 to 7.5:20 strengthens the optimized role of nickel doping on the physical-chemical properties of 7.5W/Fe2O3 catalyst, and there exists a synergetic promotional effect of nickel doping and glucose dosage on its NH3-SCR activity.
coredata.dc:title: Promotional effect of nickel doping on the W/Fe2O3 catalyst for selective catalytic reduction of NO x with NH3
